stem: Which of the following features favour Rathke’s cleft cyst rather than craniopharyngioma?
options: Involvement of suprasellar and sellar regions
explanation: Rathkes cleft cysts do not calcify. They affect women to men in a 2:1 ratio and adults from 40-60 years of age. They cause variable MR appearances depending on protein content of cyst. They can rarely show enhancement
reference: Rao VJ et al. Imaging characteristics of common suprasellar lesions with emphasis on MRI findings. Clinical Radiology 2008; 63(8): 939-947

stem: A 38-year-old male with Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) stopped taking his retrovirals 6 months ago and now presents with confusion. CT brain shows non-enhancing hypodensities, with apparent dilated perivascular spaces, although these were not present on a CT brain from 2 years ago. What is the most likely cause?
explanation: More commonly cryptococcus meningitis but cryptococcus or gelatinous pseudocysts reside in dilated perivascular spaces
reference: Rao VJ et al. Imaging characteristics of common suprasellar lesions with emphasis on MRI findings. Clinical Radiology 2008; 63(8): 939-947

stem: A 30-year-old male with recurrent Transient Ischemic Attacks (TIAs) and a history of migraine with aura undergoes CT brain. Subcortical infarcts are identified raising suspicion of cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts (CADASIL). Which is the most characteristically involved location for subcortical infarcts?
explanation: A young patient with migraines, auras, TIAs or subcortical strokes should raise suspicion of CADASIL. Subcortical infarcts are characteristically in the anterior temporal pole and external capsule but may involve C, D and E
reference: Downer JJ et al. Symmetry in computed tomography of the brain: the pitfalls. Clinical Radiology 2009; 64(3): 298-306

stem: A 40-year-old with headache, confusion, seizures and visual disturbance has a CT showing low attenuation involving the cortex and subcortical white matter in both occipital lobes. Diffusion weighted MR shows no restriction. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: These are typical imaging findings but the abnormalities are not always reversible or posterior
reference: Downer JJ et al. Symmetry in computed tomography of the brain: the pitfalls. Clinical Radiology 2009; 64(3): 298-306

stem: Which is the best answer describing neuro-imaging features of pre-eclampsia?
options: Most frequent abnormality on MR is high signal change on T2/fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR)
Lesions are in subcortical white matter only
Majority of lesions progress to infarction
Cerebral vasospasm is common in mild to moderate pre-eclampsia
answer: Most frequent abnormality on MR is high signal change on T2/fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR)
explanation: Lesions are in deep and subcortical white matter, pons and basilar territories. They may be unilateral or bilateral and the majority are reversible although some can progress to infarction. Vasospasm is uncommon in mild to moderate pre-eclampsia

stem: MRI of a mass in the parotid tail shows a well-circumscribed heterogeneous lesion with mixed cystic and enhancing solid components. Earlier US showed vessels in a hilar distribution with branches in the septa of the structure. There is no lymphadenopathy. What is the likely cause?
options: Pseudoaneurysm from a branch of the external carotid artery
explanation: Warthin’s tumours are benign salivary gland tumours, accounting for 6-10% of all parotid tumours. Warthin’s tumours are bilateral in 15% of cases
reference: Dineen R et al. Imaging of acute neurological conditions in pregnancy and the puerperium. Clinical Radiology 2005; 60(11): 1156-1170

stem: Which of the following is a cause of cerebellar atrophy with cerebral atrophy?
explanation: B-E are causes of cerebellar atrophy without cerebral atrophy
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 234

stem: A CT brain of a 25-year-old male with a head injury but no focal neurology shows no acute abnormality. A thin cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) density is noted between the frontal horns of the lateral ventricles in the midline. Which is the diagnosis?
explanation: Occurs in 80% of term infants and 15% of adults. Rarely may dilate and cause obstructive hydrocephalus
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 236

stem: Which brain tumour has the greatest incidence across all age groups?
explanation: Gliomas consist of astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas, paragangliomas, ganglogliomas and medulloblastomas
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 238

stem: Which of the following is an extra-axial posterior fossa tumour in adults?
explanation: Other extra-axial posterior fossa masses include acoustic neuroma, meningioma, chordoma and epidermoid
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 239

stem: Which is the most prevalent intraventricular tumour?
explanation: Ependymomas followed by astrocytoma are the most common
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 241

stem: Which is the cause of low attenuation in the basal ganglia?
explanation: Other causes increase carbon monoxide poisoning, barbituate intoxication, hypoxia, hypoglycaemia and lacunar infarcts
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 244

stem: On review of an MRI of a complex case marked hypointensity of the globus pallidus is noted on T2W1, surrounding a higher intensity centre, ‘eye of the tiger sign’. Which is the most likely cause?
explanation: Due to excess iron accumulation, a central gliosis is associated with Haltervorden-Spatz disease, dementia, retinitis pigmentosa, X-linked disorders with mental retardation, atrophy and Parkinsonian disorders
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 241

stem: Which of the following features describes an intra-axial mass?
options: Buckling of grey and white matter
explanation: B-E are extra-axial features
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 246

stem: Which of the following favours an arachnoid rather than an epidermoid cyst?
options: Deviates from CSF on proton density
explanation: A and C-E are features of epidermoid cyst. A and C demonstrate CSF-like density and have smooth margins
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 276

stem: A 40-year-old male has a CT brain to investigate seizures. Which of the following best describes a cavernoma?
options: Popcorn appearance with high SI centre on T1+T2
Most commonly occurs in the cerebellum
answer: Popcorn appearance with high SI centre on T1+T2
explanation: Cavernomas are most commonly located in subcortical regions and are hypodense areas which can calcify. They are associated with minimal mass effect/oedema. Cavernomas can undergo haemorrhagic change and are associated with seizures
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 273

stem: Which of the following associations favour Chiari I rather than Chiari II malformation?
explanation: Syringohydromyelia, hydrocephalus, malformation of small bones and spine are also associations of Type I Chiari malformation

stem: Which of the following best describes imaging changes in a colloid cyst?
options: Most commonly causes symmetrical enlargement of lateral ventricles
explanation: Protein content/paramagnetic effect of magnesium Mg2+/calcium Ca2+/, Iron Fe, in a cyst cause increased T1 and T2 SI. Colloid cysts appear iso/hyperdense on NCCT. They can occasionally widen septum pellucidum and cause asymmetrical enlargement of the lateral ventricles
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 277-278

stem: Which is the most common location for epidermoid in the Central Nervous System (CNS)?
explanation: Located in CPA in 40%, accounting for 5% of CPA tumours
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 286

stem: Which of the following is not typical of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)?
options: Hyperintensity on T2 in head of caudate and putamen
explanation: No gadolinium enhancement and no white matter involvement
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 303

stem: Which of the following favours dural meningeal carcinomatosis rather than leptomeningeal carcinomatosis?
options: Short discontinuous thin sections of enhancement
Thin area of subarachnoid enhancement following convulsions of gyri
Invasion of underlying brain with mass effect and oedema
answer: Short discontinuous thin sections of enhancement
explanation: Dural meningeal carcinomatosis is rarely associated with positive cytology and involves localised or diffuse curvilinear enhancement underneath inner table in expected position of dura
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 306

stem: Which is the cause of a cystic rather than a haemorrhagic cause of brain metastases?
explanation: Squamous cell lung cancer and adenocarcinoma of the lung cause cystic metastasis to the brain. Answers B-E are causes of haemorrhagic metastases
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 309-310

stem: Which is the most common location of oligodendroglioma?
explanation: Most commonly involve cortical and subcortical white matter, occasionally through corpus callosum as butterfly glioma
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 320

stem: Which of the following best describes the typical appearance of intracranial haemorrhage in the late subacute phase (8-30 days)?
explanation: B represents early subacute haemorrhage, C represents acute (12-72 hours), D represents hyperacute (less than 12 hours) and E represents chronic haemorrhage (> 1 month)
reference: Chapman S and Nakielny R (2003) Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis. 4th edition. London: Saunders Ltd. p. 404

stem: A combination of subependymal nodules, giant cell astrocytomas, white matter lesion and retinal phakomatoses suggests:
explanation: These are all features of tuberous sclerosis
reference: Chapman S and Nakielny R (2003) Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis. 4th edition. London: Saunders Ltd. p. 450-451

stem: A 20-year-old woman has a right-sided proptosis, chemosis and bruit over the orbit. On MRI she is found to have dense enhancement of the right-sided extra-ocular muscles with dilatation of the right cavernous sinus and periorbital soft tissues. Angiography reveals abnormal early opacification of a dilated left cavernous sinus and superior ophthalmic vein. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: MR angiography shows reversal of flow through the Superior Ophthalmic Vein (SOV), rapid progress of proptosis, visual loss or raised intracranial pressure requiring emergency treatment

stem: A 60-year-old woman with mild proptosis undergoes a CT which shows enlargement of the bellies of the medial, and to a lesser extent, lateral rectus muscle. Tendons appear normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Sparing of muscle tendons is typical. Most cases are bilateral

stem: A follow-up of a young man under the care of the neuro-oncologists reveals a drop in metastases. Which statement is most true?
options: Drop metastases tend to be in the upper spine
Metastases within the spinal canal are usually ventral
Glioblastoma is the commonest cause of drop metastases
Are associated with positive CSF cytology in approximately 10% of cases
Usually demonstrates homogenous enhancement with contrast
answer: Usually demonstrates homogenous enhancement with contrast
explanation: Drop metastases are usually dorsal in location in the spinal canal. Medulloblastomas are the most common cause of drop metastases. A higher percentage of CSF cytology is positive

stem: Which is the most common imaging finding in neurosarcoidosis?
options: Grey matter lesions enhancing on MR
explanation: Basilar meninges often involved. B-E are recognised imaging findings. Spinal disease is less common than brain disease and findings include intramedullary lesions and intrathecal nodular masses
reference: Provenzale, JM and Nelson, RC (1998) Duke Radiology Case Review: Imaging, Differential Diagnosis, and Discussion. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 321

stem: In herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 encephalitis:
options: Early CT findings include hyperdensity in one or both temporal lobes
Avid contrast enhancement in the temporal lobes is often present on C7
MR shows avid contrast enhancement in the temporal lobes
The basal ganglia are typically spared
Signal abnormalities are usually persistent even after drug treatment
answer: The basal ganglia are typically spared
explanation: Early CT findings may show medial temporal hypodensity. Areas poorly enhance on CT and MR. Signal abnormalities often decrease in response to treatment

stem: A patient with a genetic condition and known bilateral renal cysts undergoes MRI brain showing a cystic lesion with mural nodule. This finding is associated with:
explanation: 1⁄3 haemangioblastomas are purely solid, 1⁄3 are cystic with mural nodes and 1⁄3 are cystic with a more complex solid component
reference: Provenzale, JM and Nelson, RC (1998) Duke Radiology Case Review: Imaging, Differential Diagnosis, and Discussion. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 327

stem: Tram track gyriform calcification is most likely to be seen in:
explanation: Other features include cerebral atrophy with thickening of skull vault and surface enhancement, enlarged choroid plexus and enlarged medullary/subependymal veins. Choroid angiomas may be present
reference: Chapman S and Nakielny R (2003) Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis. 4th edition. London: Saunders Ltd. p. 451

stem: A 2cm mass is seen on MR at the left CPA with uniform enhancement and high SI on T2 and dural tail. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: Broad based attachment to petrous bone. More homogenous SI and less bright T2. Uniform enhancement distinguishes from vestibular schwannoma
reference: Chapman S and Nakielny R (2003) Aids to Radiological Differential Diagnosis. 4th edition. London: Saunders Ltd. p. 469

stem: A 40-year-old woman under investigation for hypoparathyroidism undergoes ultrasound of the neck. Which is the best answer regarding parathyroid adenoma?
options: Usually indistinguishable from margin of thyroid gland
explanation: Parathyroid adenomas are typically well circumscribed, round or oval hypoechoic nodules. They are usually low signal on T1 and high on T2. However, they may appear as high signal on both in the presence of haemorrhagic change. Parathyroid adenomas are usually hyperdense on CT
reference: Ahuja AT et al. Imaging for primary hyperparathyroidism-what beginners should know. Clinical Radiology 2004; 59(11): 967–976

stem: A 60-year-old with treated SCC of the oropharynx undergoes ultrasound neck to evaluate a new swelling. Which feature most likely indicates malignant nodes?
explanation: Matting is associated with tubercular lymph nodes. Increased peripheral vessels is a feature of malignant nodes
reference: Ahuja A et al. Sonography of neck lymph nodes. Part II: abnormal lymph nodes. Clinical Radiology 2003; 58(5): 359-366

stem: Concerning carotid body tumours:
options: Usually painful, pulsatile, mass below the angle of the jaw
explanation: Carotid body tumours are painless pulsatile vascular masses, hyperintense on T2 and heterogeneously isointense on T1 with avid enhancement. Multiple flow voids are usually seen on MRI

stem: Which of the following features favours extradural rather than subdural haematoma?
explanation: Both are extra-axial and can be of mixed attenuation. Although skull fractures are more common in EDH, this cannot be the single best answer as EDH cross dural attachments are limited by cranial sutures

stem: Which of the following most favours ameloblastoma compared with odontogenic keratocyst?
explanation: Ameloblastomas grow in the buccolingual direction and are expansile
reference: Macanovic M et al. Incidental bony pathology when reporting trauma orthopantomograms. Ameloblastomas grow in the buccolingual direction and are expansile. Clinical Radiology 2010; 65(10): 842-849

stem: Which feature indicates orbital meningioma compared with optic nerve glioma?
explanation: Other features of meningioma include calcification, homogenous enhancement and hyperostosis

stem: Which of the following is the most common cause of pulsatile tinnitus?
explanation: Glomus tumour is the most common cause of pulsatile tinnitus

stem: Considering Moyamoya disease in adults:
options: Multiple small flow voids are characteristic
Presentation with ischemia is more common in adults than in children
answer: Multiple small flow voids are characteristic
explanation: Multiple flow voids are due to hypertrophied lenticulostriate arteries. Children more often present with ischemia and infarct in cortical/subcortical areas. Adults more often present with haemorrhage than children, but when infarcts do occur, they are most often in the deep white matter. The disease can involve the posterior circulation. The supraclinoid MCA is the first to be involved
reference: Kuroda S et al. Moyamoya disease: current concepts and future perspectives. Lancet Neurology 2008; 7(11): 1056-1066

stem: Which is a cause of solitary dense pedicle rather than erosion/absence?
explanation: Osteoblastoma is a cause of a solitary dense pedicle

stem: Which is most likely to represent an intramedullary mass lesion?
explanation: Other intramedullary masses include astrocytomas are dermoids (lipoma/teratomas), acutely expanding infarcts and haematoma

stem: Which is the most common cause of erosion of the odontoid peg?
explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis is the most common cause of erosion of the odontoid peg

stem: Which is the most common location for toxoplasmosis?
explanation: 75% of cases are in the basal ganglia

stem: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy has a predilection for:
explanation: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy has a predilection for the parieto-occipital region
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 324-325

stem: Which of the following is an extraconal extraorbital lesion, rather than an extraconal intraorbital lesion?
options: Squamous cell carcinoma of the sinus
answer: Squamous cell carcinoma of the sinus
explanation: Other causes are lymphoma, adenocarcinoma, adenoid cystic carcinoma, mucoceles and paranasal sinusitis

stem: Which of the following is a case of increased radiotracer uptake in the thyroid gland?
explanation: Other causes include early thyroiditis, hyperthyroidism, and rebound after withdrawal of anti-thyroid medications
reference: Dahnert W (2007) Radiology Review Manual. 6th edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. p. 363

stem: On a thyroid radioisotope study, which is a cause of a hot thyroid nodule?
explanation: Other causes include autonomous adenoma and, very rarely, thyroid cancer. Any hot nodule on Tc-99m should be imaged with I-123 to differentiate between autonomous and cancerous lesions

stem: In the staging of supraglottic laryngeal cancer, which indicates stage T3 disease?
options: Tumour confined to the site of origin
explanation: Stage T3 disease includes tumour limited to the larynx with cord fixation or extension to post-cricoid area, and medial wall of the pyriform sinus/pre-epiglottc space
reference: Connor S. Laryngeal cancer: how does the radiologist help? Cancer Imaging 2007; 28(7): 93-103
